(John 12:37-40)

So you see, if people would just take Jesus at His word, they would be able to understand. The problem is many people are blinded and always inject their own false meaning into everything. The Mystery of the Grail -> The Crisis of the Modern World -> The Reign of Quantity and the Signs of the Times -> Revolt Against the Modern World -> Men Among the Ruins -> Ride the Tiger -> Initiation and Spiritual Realization -> Perspectives on Initiation

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21601485
It's mostly his method that I feel is the problem. Dialectic is a genius tool for finding truth in the material world, but as soon as you touch on abstracts like faith or piety or justice you really lose the plot. That's why Plato's quest of induction feels doomed. The Socratic approach all too easily leads into ethical dilemmas like, "Is it okay to kill and eat one's crewmate in a shipwreck scenario if it means the other sailors might survive?". I haven't read Kant, but he seems to answer this via the categorical imperative.

Plato and his advocates never seem to make progress with his approach. I'm not denying the concept of metaphyics btw, or the existence of forms. I just doubt that using dialectic to know the forms is really possible

Like the teacher was trying to comfort him, maybe a little too touchy, but with no ulterior motives, and it played into Holden’s disillusionment and how he colored the whole thing. But again maybe the teacher was a pervert and it’s the theme of loss of innocence. I should reread it soon. It’s been a while and Salinger is a writer where you can always pull more from each time

>>21600984
If you are alluding to Dostoevsky’s worst novels, then, indeed, I dislike intensely The Brothers Karamazov and the ghastly Crime and Punishment rigamarole. No, I do not object to soul-searching and self-revelation, but in those books the soul, and the sins, and the sentimentality, and the journalese, hardly warrant the tedious and muddled search. Dostoyevsky’s lack of taste, his monotonous dealings with persons suffering with pre-Freudian complexes, the way he has of wallowing in the tragic misadventures of human dignity – all this is difficult to admire. I do not like this trick his characters have of ”sinning their way to Jesus” or, as a Russian author, Ivan Bunin, put it more bluntly, ”spilling Jesus all over the place."Crime and Punishment’s plot did not seem as incredibly banal in 1866 when the book was written as it does now when noble prostitutes are apt to be received a little cynically by experienced readers. Dostoyevsky never really got over the influence which the European mystery novel and the sentimental novel made upon him. The sentimental influence implied that kind of conflict he liked—placing virtuous people in pathetic situations and then extracting from these situations the last ounce of pathos. Non-Russian readers do not realize two things: that not all Russians love Dostoevsky as much as Americans do, and that most of those Russians who do, venerate him as a mystic and not as an artist. He was a prophet, a claptrap journalist and a slapdash comedian. I admit that some of his scenes, some of his tremendous farcical rows are extraordinarily amusing. But his sensitive murderers and soulful prostitutes are not to be endured for one moment—by this reader anyway. Dostoyevsky seems to have been chosen by the destiny of Russian letters to become Russia’s greatest playwright, but he took the wrong turning and wrote novels.

>>21601081
It's a reference to the fact that Aeneas is not the same kind of hero as Achilles or Odysseus. Achilles is the strong, furious and fearless warrior, dominated by impulse. Odysseus is cunning, smart and resourceful, capable of extricating himself from problems using his wits. Both their traits serve them well in those particular situations in which Homer puts them.
Aeneas is, on the other hand, a founder of cities. He brings over the penates from Troy to refound it in Italy. His quality is that of a pious, pioneering man, for he needs the favor of the gods for the survival of his cities. He indeed prays a lot and stops all the time to sacrifice for the gods. He's not an outstanding warrior or a cunning bastard, but his traits suit him in his role.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21599347

Lovecraft's entire neurosis was centered around sex, and was quite litterally a very asexual person. This is not to say that it was lack of sex that made him neurotic, there is quite a distinction here. It was the activity of childbearing, lineage and mutation that freaked him out. His early infantile paranoia stemmed from the Oedipal fantasy that he was somehow a bastard, or a half-breed. While this fantasy attached itself to the well-known prejudices of his time, such as racism and sexism, it was really this primal fear of being a "mullato" that characterises all of his work.

Lovecraft is so fascinating because we have an insight of how such nightmares are expressed in literature. Its even more fascinating because a lot of Lovecrafts ideas came to him in his dreams. The idea of the "monster" being also this proto-plasmatic , primitive protozoa but also very physical is also very much in the zeitgeist of his time, with scientiffic discoveries in physics and biology making leaps in his time, exposing anxieties about human limitation.

>>21603569

>>21603625 is okay but incomplete advice. do you want to read philosophy as in you want to read it like literature, keep abreast of The Great Conversation, or do you want to know what's going on in contemporary philosophy?

if the first, buy Plato's dialogues individually. don't get the complete works. shit translation. hackett's editions are good, as are penguin's. plato is a joy to read -- fluid dialogues -- but be warned that his strawmen are just that, strawmen. plato will assert a position and put up the dumbest fucking counterarguments against it and then trot around like he's solved philosophy. so know if you disagree with plato, you're not alone. many do.

hackett also puts out an excellent selected presocratics, which you can read if you'd like, but you really need reams of secondary literature to extract their value, importance, and influence. still, worth reading.

you can read aristotle if you'd like but be forewarned he's exceptionally difficult. start with his ethics, then his politics. you can read his litcrit if you'd like. avoid his metaphysics unless you're prepared to sink a few years into it -- aristotle's metaphysics is comparable in difficulty to a terminal pure math degree. foundational, revolutionary, yes, but it's very hard to overstate its difficulty.

after that, jump ahead a few centuries. read Descartes's Meditations, then Hume's An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding. both are wonderful writers which is rare in philosophy. hume especially. that ought to keep you busy for a while.

if it's the second, google around for some "introduction to philosophy of mind" or "introduction to metaphysics" textbooks and libgen that shit. they'll contain seminal analytic papers as well as recaps of most broadly held positions. it'll take you a while but worth it. philosophy's separated into disciplines; politics, ethics, aesthetics, epistemology, metaphysics, and philosophy of mind. just pick the fields you're most interested in and dive into those textbooks.

have fun anon philosophy is wonderful. remember there is no idea so strange it hasn't already been said by some philosopher or another

>>21555032
A very good and tricky question. We know through Aristotle and quotations of Speussipus and Xenocrates that the latter two heads of the Academy departed self-consciously departed from Plato's view, apparently, of the Form Numbers, and the latter two in quotation also argue that Aristotle misunderstands or misrepresents Plato's views; that the Academy between then and Cicero's time became more skeptical leaning makes it hard to establish just what the dogmas or traditions of the school were. Numenius, who Plotinus read (but didn't necessarily take as the final word) seems to combine views of both the early and skeptical school by claiming Euthyphro was written to criticize popular Athenian religious practice uing the ridiculous Euthyphro as a proxy.

Porphry's bography seems to admit that there's innovation in Plotinus, but it's not clear what he thinks the full extent of that is:

>"Plotinus’ writing is concise, but packed with meaning; brief and more abundant in ideas than in words, inspiring and passionate about almost everything; a *combination of personal insight and respect for tradition*. Stoic and Peripatetic doctrines are blended into his writings, though they are not obvious; and it contains the concentrated essence of
Aristotle’s Metaphysics."

Aristotle's commentator Alexander of Aphrodisias takes Aristotle and Plato to be opposed, but Plotinus seems to take them as either harmonized or harmonizable; the treatise on Potentiality and Actuality are clearly focused on Aristotelian nomenclature, though perhaps with adjustments or corrects to fit them to what Plotinus takes to be Plato's views or an innovation acceptable to such (for Plato on Potentiality, cf. Theaetetus and Sophist).

There's also some kind of acknowledgement of having to grapple with texts, presumably including the Platonic corpus, but also a suggestion of how to read:

>"For three days I, Porphyry, questioned his account of the sense in which the soul
was ‘in’ the body, and he patiently went through the arguments. Someone
called Thaumasius, who was studying universal propositions, joined the
seminar and wanted to hear Plotinus speaking on texts: he could not stand
Porphyry’s responding and questioning. However, Plotinus said: ‘But if
we cannot solve Porphyry’s difficulties when he asks them, how will we be
able to say anything at all when faced with a text?’"

There's some sense that he's not merely reiterating the teachings passed down to him:

>"I decided to set out this letter to substantiate the claim that there were those who, during his lifetime, thought that Plotinus made his reputation by passing off Numenius’ doctrines as his own." (But compare "On another occasion, Origen appeared at a seminar. Plotinus blushed deeply and wanted to leave. Origen asked him to keep speaking, but he said that all desire to do so is crushed when the speaker sees that he is speaking to those who know what he is going to say.")

(Cont.)

>>21565106
The glossary of my edition (Gerson) renders it as substance. I'll write out the entry here:
>Substance (ούσιά ): also substance, Substantiality, substantiality. Term with both Platonic and Peripatetic provenance. When used Platonically, Substance refers to Intellect or to any distinct Being in the intelligible world; Substantiality refers to the essence of Intellect or of any distinct Being. Intelligibles, that is, Platonic Forms, are variously referred to as Substances or the Subtantialiy of Intellect. When used Peripatetically , the term 'substance' refers to an individual 'this something'; 'substantiality' refers to the essence of a substance, that is, its core reality or being. For Plotinus, true ontological primacy is found in Substance and Substantiality, not in substance and substantiality. Nevertheless, Plotinus follows Aristotle in making a distinction between Substance and Substantiality in the intelligible world which reflects Aristotle's distinction between substance and substantiality in the sensible world. The adjective substantial, Substantial usually indicate and implicit contrast. Thus, Substantial Numbers are contrasted with quantitative (i.e., non-substantial) number.

>The meaning of the word "ousia" has evolved over time in the history of philosophy. Originally, the word "ousia" comes from Greek philosophy, and it was used by the pre-Socratic philosophers to refer to the underlying substance or essence of things. >In later Hellenistic philosophy, particularly in Neoplatonism, the concept of ousia took on a more mystical and metaphysical meaning, where it was understood as the ultimate reality or ultimate being, which is transcendent, eternal, and unchanging. It's also important to note that the word Ousia has been translated to "Being" by Heidegger in his work, and he developed the concept of Dasein, or human existence, as the way to understand Being.

>how legitimate do we think is the claim that the Plotonian system is a genuine continuation of the Platonic project/system?
Why is that even important? Plato himself didn't write down any systematic explanation of his own philosophy. He wrote dialogues that present a dialectic and let the reader reach their own conclusions on the matter based on the arguments. They're made to be extrapolated. Plotinus exegetes Plato in the same way Christians exegete the Bible and the result is a beautiful flowering of the themes Plato touched on.

If you're going to be an autist then it's not likely Plato thought everything that Plotinus ascribes to his philosophy but that's only because Plotinus takes Plato and builds his works into a full fledged holistic philosophical worldview. Plotinus transcends Plato and in that regard whether or not he's adhering to Platos own personal philosophy is irrelevant.

>>21581548
>>21581701
This is very Platonic as an attitude. The Platonic philosopher's love of truth differs from the modern virtue of probity, the latter tending toward evangelism of truth (because probity is a lingering Christian virtue). In Plato's case, there's no automatic necessity to share the truth, if, for example, the philosopher perceives that someone has a disposition or character such that the truth might somehow make them worse.

Porphry backs this attitude up in Plotinus' biography when he notes as an aside the latter's reluctance to share his writings until he'd figured someone's character out.

>>21590492
I don’t want to spoil your exploration and interpretation of Plotinus with an “authoritative” answer, as this sounds like new and exciting to you, but this is an established point in Neoplatonic scholarship. I’ll put it in spoiler tags in case you want to ignore it and figure it out for yourselves. There is a one-to-one correspondence between Plato’s demiurge and one hypostasis and the demiurge is the nous. Plotinus and the other neos synthesized Plato and Aristotle and identified Plato’s demiurge with Aristotle’s Nous, but with a twist: the Ideas or Intelligible world that the demiurge looks to as a model for the sensible world are within himself, just like Ari’s Nous is “thought thinking itself”. It also makes sense when you remember that in the Timaeus the demiurge also creates the world soul. But in Plotinus’ case the Nous actually emanates Soul.

Ezra Pound was right (as usual) pointing out that Anglos have a strange disdain for translations as works of English literature, whereas the French and Italians never had any issues listing translations as some of the best work in their literary history. They don't hesitate to consider them superior to the originals in some cases, and not without reason, see Amyot vs Plutarque or Galland versus the pulp original of the Arabian Nights, both of which were the basis of English translations for a while.
A related effect is that the quality of translations is usually lower in English, though I don't know which is cause and which is effect. I understand Wilbur is an exception while not better than Moliere.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In what order should I read him?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21600155
Aside from Hour of the Dragon, they were written to work as stand-alone episodes from Conan's life, so literally any order is fine.

The Del Ray editions publish them in the order they were written, along with unfinished drafts in appendices, which is interesting to see how R.E. Howard developed the character.

The single-volume Complete Chronicles has them in publication order, which is cool to see the order that readers first encountered.

And there are several attempts at an internal chronology, but none is perfect because there are obvious gaps not coveres by the stories. Dale Rippke's order is possibly the most consistent and is used for the newer Dark Horse comics series.

How do you start writing a poem, and how long does it take you to write 4-8 lines? I have recently started to (attempt to) write a weekly poem for my wife, despite having very little experience in the field, and my process so far is as follows:
>decide on an image I want to use as a "theme", like the first warm sunny day after winter
>make what I as an amateur have dubbed the "heart" of the poem, meaning a central rhyme that I will then build the rest of the poem around
>add sentences around this "heart" of the poem until it makes me cringe
>remove what I can until I cringe a little less

So far, I have not given my wife any of the poems as they all make me feel like a pseud, but I have at least taken a step toward being the person I want to be.

What is your process for writing poetry?

I’m a bi male. I’ve written a hundred poems in my 20 years of romance. When I first started I let my heart tell the pen what to do. I would write would write without caring about what I wrote and just gave it to her. She would ask me about stuff. I was in school was I started so I was inundated by text reading and other studies so I’m sure some of that bleed over. Eventually I could write around a theme. I think you have to earn theme poems. I would start with the one fish two fish red fish blue fish style poems to get accustomed to just writing poems. This is a purely creative venture. I’m sure you can get taught or learn what a poem is or how it’s constructed but until you take the time to get your poem kill count up it will always be a learning lesson. I can write a poem in minutes and listen to my heart or I spend a little more time to construct a themed poem which would take me maybe 8 hrs of time toying around with it. I hope this helps from my anecdote.

ChatGPT has greatly increased my ability to understand a book while reading it. This has REVOLUTIONIZED the effectiveness of my studies. You should all try it.

>>21564359
try "Athenaze", you can even ehm borrow it from the link in the OP if you want to give it a try, these kind of books were made for people to take it slow and comfy if you don't have time constraints
I used it and I'm reading both Thucydides and Homer right now
knowing Latin though does help a lot, but it's not necessary, it will just make the process easier

to simplify it a lot you will learn initially the Greek spoken by Plato in the Athens of the fifth-fourth century, which is the basis of Koine, which largely is a simplified version of it, and it's also a sister dialect to Ionic, which is the base of Homer
once your Attic will be good enough, moving to other dialects won't be too hard, especially Ionic; Homer it's kind of it's own thing, as it's an artificial poetic language whose main challenge is really the lexicon not so much the odd forms which you get used to fairly easily

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21584684
>I've heard of a Greek who learned Ancient Greek by working gradually backward in time.
This method is actually the best way to learn any ancient language and it's not up for debate in a technical sense. The problem is that even though the period from when you start something like Epic Greek to the point that you can understand it fluently is much shorter, the overall study time it takes you to master Modern Greek, then Byzantine, then Koine, Attic, etc before you get to Homer will be a grueling grind if you don't actually give a fuck about modern Greece or Byzantium and you just wanted to read the Illiad and Odyssey. So you basically have the option of studying Ancient Greek upfront and taking maybe 3-5 years to understand it fluently or going backwards in time over 3-5 years and only needing a few months towards the end to grasp Homer. But it still can take the same amount of time. But at least with the former you are spending all that time on the thing that you are actually interested in.

The only thing that would make me do this approach would be if near native comprehension was my #1 goal above all else. If that's your goal, this method is without a doubt the way to go. Otherwise, I wouldn't bother.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21603780
>LLPSI
It's been a while since we had a good meaningless pseudo-intellectual argument about textbooks, so I'll take the bait.

>So should I start with this to learn Latin?
No. You should buy a textbook with English in it, read it, do the exercises. By the time you have done with 1/4-1/2 of that textbook, you should then start working through LLPSI. You will fly through the first 20 or so chapters without issue if you do it the way I recommended.

>I was recommended also Familia Romana.
Ignore any subsequent advice from whoever, whatever, or wherever you got this advice. FR is a graded reader. A graded reader is just a text written for learners that is graded for difficulty. This is not a textbook. It's good reading practice, but trying to force yourself to learn using this as a sole resource from the start holds no practical value and is merely an attempt to participate in a semi-religious purity ritual where you follow some arbitrary rules given to you by people online because they said it's the "natural method". You need to read copious amounts of Latin to get fluent, but taking a month or so to familiarize yourself with the grammar by working through an actual textbook will allow you to get much more out of your graded readers like LLPSI.

A massive argument will proceed to derail the thread, so maybe just take my advice and mute the thread to preserve your sanity. If you don't like my advice, that's also ok. Pick something, read it, and finish it. This will also work eventually, although it may take longer. The important part is that you finish whatever you start.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21603808
Peasant leisure was monopolised by multiple oppressive systems of extraction, from being literally owned as slaves or serfs, through land bound and "free" peasants, into small farming. Lords could and did extract sudden requirements from "bound" peasants who were incapable of resisting sudden extractions..

Priests, Monks, Imams or Rabbis could also force extraordinary extractions, or ordinary extractions such as worship in a foreign language, forced singing, threats of future torture for "voluntary" donations. On the other hand at times and places people earnestly wanted to "live for christ" by secular rules (berghards et beguines), or spend all day singing, or read a funny book and debate the series of semi-anonymous shit posts, etc.

Finally, the village itself demanded and ordered life. It wasn't always voluntary drunken fucking on overripe grapes while shitting yourself from overripe grapes. Sometimes it was involuntary drunken fucking on overripe grapes while shitting yourself on overripe grapes, she pins you down, vomiting red grape juice in your face and sharts as she mounts you.

CORRESPONDINGLY, "leisure" in capital is the reproduction of labour power. 8-8-8 was in the bosses' interest to have rested labour who would spend on products to improve the quality of labour supplied.

So concepts of Leisure necessarily involve consumptive repression or repressive desublimation.

posts.com:
Nobody seems to notice this but Peterson's cognitive binary (Order/Chaos) replaces Jung's (Logos/Eros) but he acts like Jung never had one. Eros is unity/connection and Logos is multiplicity/discrimination; this binary works because all phenomena manifests as a unity which contains multiplicity. This can easily be demonstrated with the example of an inch: a unit of distance such as an inch exists as a span between zero and one, and within that span you can create infinite decimal subdivisions but you can never escape the fact that in order to have the phenomena even numerically there has to be a unity that contains multiplicity. This is what Aristotle said about time and what Kant described when he said "all bodies are extended".
When Logos/Eros is replaced with Order/Chaos the feminine category switches from connection to something that can only be compared to disconnection. Order by itself simply refers to discrimination but that creates a problem being that discrimination only creates a category when unity contains it, otherwise the discrimination functions as a solution to chaos (which is why Peterson said he believes the purpose of the left hemisphere is to prevent the right hemisphere from having to turn on, as he theorizes that the role of the right hemisphere is to detect anomaly which the left tries to integrate). The result is discrimination ad infinitum which results in the identity/phenomena being atomized into obliteration which is the same problem Guenon identified with materialism and individualism in Crisis of the Modern World. Identities are dependent on unity (group) and individualism nullifies identity by assuming multiplicity is dominant which de facto rejects group identity.

A boundary contains something which means it is a unit, which is why I used the example of an inch which is essentially what Aristotle said about time and what Kant said about space.
In order to have a moment in time you actually need a duration between two "times", just as in order to have a unit of distance you need point A and point B. When you count one second or one inch, what you count is a grouping between 0 and 1. The outside boundary is the unit and any multiplicity that follows has to be subdivided from said unit. Any multiplicity whatsoever has to be contained in a unity. When the boundary exists without the unit the multiplicity is eliminated, which is to say you have a tick mark on a tape measure that isn't connected to another tick mark, effectively representing 0.

If I was a Luddite I might say the anti-technological stance solves nearly every problem modern man is facing. Of course, these solutions are unacceptable to all the people who cannot survive without technology or do not believe they could live a good life without it. Surely a Luddite would argue that the psychological stress placed on humans in a technological system are so great that it will eventually fail, so the longer we delay anti-tech solutions the greater the disaster. The perils we endured with more primitive technologies were pains we evolved to suffer and endure. They were natural for us, and modern society is unnatural to us. The use of industrial technology prohibits us from expressing our natural behaviors in a similar way that animals in a zoo are stultified by their enclosures.

I think the best anti anything strategy is to talk to people. I'm not an authoritarian, so I wouldn't want to force anyone to do anything. Tactics and strategies assume a position of authority.

>>21595464
This is an obviously false belief, and is the bedrock of your ideological blindness. It's commonplace that people persist in doing things that they agree are bad for them. This can happen for a variety of reasons. The simplest form is addiction. In this case short term pleasure overshadows long term harm, even overwhelming harm, and even when the subject knows that they're hurting themselves. Addicts often express that they feel they cannot change, and so take comfort in the fact that the pleasure of the addiction at least temporarily distracts them from the harm they know they're ultimately inflicting.

Another form of acting against your own interest arises from failures of social coordination. In this case, it would obviously be in everyone's interest to change behavior, but if any one person changes their behavior alone, they are worse off. The toy model of this phenomenon is the prisoner's dilemma. People in this situation will acknowledge that the social structure is incentivizing them to do harmful things, and will acknowledge that by going along with it they are thereby creating additional social pressure for others to do the same harmful things, but will say they nevertheless cannot change, because no one else will go along with it. Thus they actively support and contribute to the thing they know is harmful.

Another form of acting against your own interest is reaping rewards today at the cost of problems to be solved later. In this case the person acknowledges that the harm they are creating outweighs the immediate benefits, but because the harm comes later, they hypothesize that they will come up with a mitigation strategy later to deal with the harms. Thus they deny that the harms will really happen, even though they don't actually know how to prevent those harms. They simply stipulate that "somehow" we will mitigate them, with unspecific appeals to belief in Progress.

It's pretty obvious that all of these psychological and social forces are at work with technology. It creates new addictions, it creates coordination problems, it creates immediate benefits in exchange for long term crises. It does also produce legitimate benefits, like certain medical technologies. And medical technology is usually what technophiles will point to. But you cannot help but notice that the vast majority of new technology is not medical and does not produce health benefits.

Some agricultural societies existed for thousands of years with relative cultural and political continuity, yet without industrialization. Egypt is the best example. As far as I'm aware, there was no policy of murdering smart people. This is not a claim that Egyptian Kingdoms were idyllic. It serves only to illustrate that industrialization is not some inviolable law of nature in long-standing civilizations.

"Smart people" can engage in all kinds of activities that don't involve advancing technological infrastructure. Even within industrial society, plenty of smart people spend their life engaged with arts, philosophy, and culture. Outside industrial society intelligent people generally use their intelligence in ways that is productive to their daily life.

This ties into a critical point that Kaczinski makes about technological development. Industrial technology is not in fact produced by smart people overcoming problems in the course of their daily life. On the contrary, technology is almost entirely produced by professional technologists who pursue this career because of a combination of intellectual satisfaction and economic incentive. The pursuit of intellectual satisfaction is what Kaczinski calls a "surrogate activity", by which he means an activity not pursued under conditions of maintaining your daily life, but rather under conditions in which industrial society meets your needs and then asks you to "do something productive".

>>21600789
There are several very different questions getting bundled together here. The first question is whether humans are better off under industrial society than the alternatives. The second is what causes industrialization to take place, and why does new technology get developed in the way and at the rate that it does. The third is what kind of measures are necessary to prevent this from happening. And the fourth is what kinds of technologies are compatible with human good, what "level of technology" a healthy society can exist at.

The concept of surrogate activities is introduced to explain the second question. Surrogate activities are not "bad for people" per se. Rather, the theory of surrogate activities partially explains why technology continues to be developed as it is, even though it has bad consequences. So the fact that a certain behavior is a surrogate activity is not a moral condemnation of it. It's just a (partial) explanation of why something is happening.

Now, whether something qualifies as "immoral under this regime" is a very loaded question. Certainly your question presumes that the answer to question three above is that we need an anti-technology political regime. But my comments in previous posts about Ancient Egypt are a challenge to this presumption. Egyptian kingdoms did not have an anti-technology ideology, but maintained political and cultural continuity for thousands of years without undergoing industrialization. What explains this? Either industrialization naturally takes many thousands of years, or not all civilizations are structured in a way that guarantees an industrial explosion. In either case it appears that an Anti-Tech Police Force is really not necessary. All that's necessary is removing the conditions that lead to rapid technological progress.

ON THE RARITY OF MATERIALS TO BUILD MODERN TECH

Here are some case studies of cultural phenomena that became part of our culture:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've read a lot on the topic. It's a subject beset by an epidemic of grifters, appeals to fake authority, etc. Forgeries are justified by magic involving deception or self-deception. Most mystical traditions are inexorably bound up in the religions that spawned them and don't make sense out of context.

I would start with the Oxford guide edited by Magee, since it is a rare, sober, scholarly survey of the field. Then see which tradition interests you most and try to read more.

The Great Courses has a solid course on Gnosticism. Their course on mysticism is somewhat shallow, but a decent overview.

Schloem is great on Kabbalah.

Magee's book on Hegel is a bad take on Hegel in that its thesis is way too strong and it cherry picks to support it, but is actually a good summary of esoterica in the Western tradition and linkages to more formal systems of thought.

For actual mystical texts, I thought Meditations on the Tarot was better than most.

Esoterica/Occult Reading List...

Basics/Ancients:
Coffin Texts
Pyramid Texts
Egyptian Book of the Dead / Book of Going Forth by Day
Zoroaster (+ Chaldean Oracles)
Hermes / Hermetica (+ Asclepius, Poimandres, & Emerald Tablet)
Hesiod
Homer
Heraclitus
Parmenides
Empedocles
Plato
Aristotle
Plotinus
Proclus
Iamblichus
The Bible - OT and NT
Nag Hammadi Library
Dead Sea Scrolls
Sefer Yetzirah
Bahir
Koran / Quran
Books of Enoch
Testament of Solomon

Medieval/Renaissance/Early Modern:
Bruno
Lull
Ficino
Dee
Agrippa
Levi
Paracelsus
Bohme
Swedenborg
Blake
De Radiis
The Zohar

Contemporary:
Fortune
Crowley
Spare
Grant
Guenon
Evola (+ Gruppo di Ur)
Eliade
Yates
Walker
Culianu
Corbin
Jung
Hillman
Kingsley
Klages
Cheak
Chumbley
Ginzburg
Wilby
Optional -- Chaos Magic (Carroll, Hine, Snell / Duke, etc.)

Eastern:
Upanishads
Baghavad Gita
Yoga Sutras
Vigyan Bhairav Tantra
Dhammapada
Heart Sutra
Diamond Sutra
Lotus Sutra
Dao De Jing
Zhuangzi
I-Ching
Secret of the Golden Flower

Academic:
Wouter Hanegraaf et al (AKA the OG of the burgeoning field of Western Esoteric Studies) -- Great starter - Western Esotericism: a Guide for The Perplexed; Great reference - Dictionary of Gnosis and Western Esotericism; Great Historiography - Esotericism and the Academy; Etc., etc., etc.; all brilliant!!!

Recommendations? Start here, go anywhere. But most importantly: M E D I T A T E & P R A C T I C E

PS: Consider studying Tarot as well! While contemporary tarot attributions are considered by most scholars nowadays to be ahistorical, they nevertheless function as a powerful esoteric / occult memnonic technique. I would suggest starting your tarot study with Mystical Origins of the Tarot for a relatively scholarly history with a good mix of theory and practice. Another fun Tarot book is Tomberg's Meditations on the Tarot, it's not really occult per se altho certainly esoteric but nevertheless it remains an excellent example of the continuing cross-pollination between occult and mainstream threads of theology and philosophy as well as the ongoing dialogue of occident and orient and esoteric and exoteric which will also become familiar to you if you follow this list.

I am convinced that as apparently widely differing and geographically and culturally separated (generally speaking) people such as Tibetan lamas of the steppes, Amerindian shamans of the American plains, dervishes and Sufis leading wandering mendicant lives, hiding out in a cave in Afghanistan, or simply even integrated into the life of their community with a simple trade or profession (from carpet-weaver to a schoolmaster), as is often enjoined to Sufis (that they get a job and fit into society instead of monkery), to Christian saints, to Indian yogis, gurus, and fakirs, can be miraculous.

It seems to have to do with the development of a certain extra inner organ of perception (a spiritual or nonphysical organ, or sense, not a physical one), or a development of the extra-dimensional ranges of the human individuality usually invisible to us (and hence associated with phenomena like miraculous healing, prophesying, clairvoyance, mind-reading, “just knowing” things one has no rational way of knowing, and the like).

(Accuse me of credulity if you like.)

However, and this is in response to your post, this is indeed where the difference between academic and experiential knowledge comes in — a Professor of Oriental Studies may not be able to genuinely satisfy your burning spiritual quest for the truth, enlightenment, or self-transformation as well as some authentic Hindu, Buddhist, or Sufi might. They might talk ABOUT the teachings, the historical circumstances, the names, dates, figures and doctrines; but this scholarship may not yet be a manifestation OF the teachings.

And furthermore (this is where it gets worst), maybe even the “leading figures” of the spiritual field you and I all love to ponder and talk about, from the Theosophists to the Traditionalists, themselves fall awry in this way at times, favoring bookish knowledge or even titillating tales over the core wisdom.

Maybe even much of the clergy, and the monks, and the lamas, and the yogis and gurus have even become inauthentic frauds and mountebanks, are simply mechanically parroting outworn traditions and basking in the respect they get from others for doing so.

Moreover — and the truly wise often have and do continue to state this, of all these and more religious traditions — even the miracle-mongering quest, the excitement of tales of the paranormal, the frenzied search for “secrets” and “mysteries,” esoteric lore and a cult to be accepted into — can be an immature orientation which itself hinders the search for self-realization or higher knowledge.

Anyway, if you still want books, I recommend P.D. Ouspensky’s “In Search of the Miraculous,” as well as a working knowledge of all the world’s major religious traditions, even shamanism, and you could even throw in the Western philosophical tradition, too. If you’re going to go on the allegorical Pilgrim’s Progress, go all the way — get massively confused and mindfucked by the abundance of paths, ways, and teachings, continually break down, remodel and continue adding innovative and unusual information to your worldview.

You may not find much respect or understanding from society at large, and may end up even more confused than when you started, but it also may be an immeasurable intangible boon. Or just choose one sect or religion and stay devoted to it and flesh out all your knowledge of it, and eternally increase your devotion to and faith in it, if you dislike an attempted universal knowledge of the world’s great religious teachings. It’s your existential dilemma — it’s your own existential freedom.

>>21601992
Good posts, and I agree. For me, the "trick" is to trick yourself into not wanting any tricks. It has to become an actual quest. You have to accept that it's a lifelong thing, that you may even only be doing it for others in the future for example, maybe in this darkened age the astral light has been blocked to such an extent that your role can only be to collate and present knowledge that will enable the light to be uncovered by some future generation. If you truly don't care about this, because truly all you care about is the truth, then you're doing something right.

But you can't cheat God either, you can't go "look how pious I am, look how little I care about the truth, so you should totally give me some siddhis and visions because I don't even want them!" These sorts of things are obvious to religious people who have meditated on them in a moral context. The famed "Catholic guilt" is one of the great "negaters" of egoistic self-enclosure, and thus one of the great "openers" onto true wisdom.

These experiences of self-negation, the solvere that precedes coagulare, are comparatively harder to come by in an the wisdom-seeking/gnostic (lowercase), because in this modern age "knowing" (gignoskein) has collapsed all the different forms of knowledge, from merely sensuous and merely ratiocinative thinking to full-fledged wisdom and nondual insight, into an amorphous single category. So when people go seeking "wisdom," they think "I want to KNOW in the highest sense," but because the category of KNOWING they are invoking is so blurry and amorphous, they think "knowing" must just be a particularly intense form of what their near-animal, sensuous-but-served-by-clever-ratiocination modern consciousness does every day. Moral/religious humility is one of the few experiences still available today that can jar one out of this initial, "sleepwalking and dreaming that one is awake" state that modern man starts in. It's one of the few great negations one can still experience today. One can then (hopefully) see an analogous process that needs to take place in the sphere of wisdom.

The cosmos only reveals itself to man once he has retracted into himself and realized how infinitesimally small he is in comparison to it. But this is because he is its antipode, microcosmos to macrocosmos. The inevitably next step after this retraction is the realization of "thou art that," of identity WITH the cosmos, and the beginning of true vision into the correspondences linking one's self with the self of the cosmos. But if you tell someone this while they're still in the sleepwalking state, they will interpret it as applying to their egoistic sleepwalker pseudo-self. They can even embark on a lifetime of fascination with the occult, and manifest minor powers from sheer will, which the blindness of delusion and also madness has plenty of, in a subordinate kind of way. Or worse, make themselves vessels for forces that delude them on purpose.

I buy all of my books second-hand and will spend a little bit extra to get a copy with a cover that I prefer. Sometimes it doesn't work out but that's fine and I don't mind, because it's just a book.

Pic related is the edition of Elric of Melniboné that I own and the cover suggests nothing of the actual contents - the book is nowhere near as dreamy, surreal or Romanesque. Also if I'm going to be spending money on something that is going to sit there after I'm finished reading it, then I want it to look somewhat appealing.

>>21585665
>Is this what it's like to get "pilled?"
Yes. As to your question, you're exhibiting a fatalistic mindset. There are people with one of two beliefs regarding their relationship with the world; the first has an external locus control in which the future is a series of uncontrollable events that happen to a person, i.e., what will happen was always going to happen regardless of the actions I take, and the second an internal locus in which the future is controllable and dirigible by his actions, i.e., what will happen is determined by the actions I take. People with the former tend towards fatalistic thinking and I speculate are higher neuroticism than the latter.

Let's roll the dice however. As you are (being) fatalistic, I'll say this whatever you do and wherever you are sorted will be sorted out after you have done it. Fatalism has a positive form where you take action because you believe that you were fated to do so. So if you wish to write, then write. You were meant to, after all, right?

Finally, striving and excellence are a struggle and largely ambiguous. They will always be so. If you don't believe it's worth it, then don't pursue it.

>>21585665
Spengler was wrong about decline. He correctly identified the process but it never occurred to him that every civilization might decline differently. His diagnosis of Western decline is the same as his diagnosis of Classical decline. This makes no sense.

It makes perfect sense that the static and ahistorical civilization of antiquity would end as he describes, in a frozen terminal state, but it makes no sense that the dynamic and moving civilization of the West would end the same way. He's already been proven wrong about the terminal state of Western art by modern film and music, art which never ossified like late Roman art did.

Western art in its "decline" just continues on forever, the only difference is it's not this big monocultural entity that it was in the 15th to 19th centuries. It's perfectly fine to still be an artist if you want.

Spengler's own pessimism massively distorted what could have been a perfect model of civilization cycles. Don't get dragged into it.

Correct. Mao outright saying "Communism is just the same shit that we've being doing for centuries; I am Qin Shi Huang, Marxist-Hegelian Dialectics is the Dao, Socialist Virtue is Ru, etc" is an example of this in practice.

It's not dying, it's just doing what all Culture-Civilizations do: they're born, they flux around a bit, and then they settle. Once they settle, they live until another Culture-Civilization murders them. They don't "die" of old age or something, they "die" by having all of their hosts (the people in whose heads the Culture-Civilization lives) co-opted by another Culture-Civilization. Apollonian Man didn't die of peak decadence or something, it died because Magian Man stole all of its people at swordpoint (the result of this is Byzantium, which was Magian).

Spengler isn't really a "cyclic" thinker in that regard, as the cycles are what WE, the humans, are subjected to, but the Culture-Civilizations are absolutely not cyclic, they're entirely linear.

As to the reason why Saturn is associated with limit, I think it has to do with two things. First, Saturn is the dimmest planet in the sky. It carries connotations of weakness, endings, the expending of strength and finality. Second, Saturn is traditionally the most external planet - if Earth is the centre, and all the other planets form concentric circles around this circle, Saturn is the final circle, the edge of the cosmos. It marks the outer limit and the end of life and light, both celestial and human. Further, as a symbol of the outer limit, it is also a symbol of time and death, hence why Saturn was also known as Kronos or the star of Kronos. Everything exists and lives on its appropriate plane, and carries on its journey, until the very end, at which point Saturn collects what is due and dispenses death - the meaning of the life is therefore forced to be constrained within a beginning and an end, giving mortal beings a kind of imperative to attend to our tasks, needs and duties - this is why Saturn is the lord of organisation, control, discipline, mastery and authority, in addition to being a lord of disaster, pain, suffering and death.

>that's literally the definition of moving the goal posts.
That was not my intention, friend. I just wanted to see if we agreed that there would be a distinction between the societies of peasants and nobility.
Forgive my lack of education but my general semblance of both peasants (which I see as agrarian) and "the natural order" comes from the novel Ishmael and some anthropology courses.
>the natural order is that of the peasant, to look after your own, your own family, but not oppress others
Agrarian cultures require expansion to have sustainable food sources for their growing population. There's only so much land so they will naturally butt up against other agrarian societies or hunter gatherers/pastoralists. This will create conflict which will often resort to violence. This will lead to oppression of others, even among other peasants (where one has better land while another does not) when we consider it's in peasants' nature to "look after their own".
Furthermore agrarian societies have advantage over others in that they can more efficiently produce large quantities of food that can be stored and distributed later. This accumulation lends itself to the benefit of specialization, say a warrior class to conquer and protect the frontier, or a political class to organize food distribution to the efforts of the warriors, etc.
I guess what I'm trying to get at is the natural order of agrarian, peasant societies is to create stratified classes by the very nature of its food accumulation.

I agree with this only somewhat
>Human hierarchical culture is not "natural".
The closest we get to natural order is hunter gatherer societies (not agrarian peasants), considering they are the basis of how we lived and biologically developed for the vast majority of our human existence. The very nature of their subsistence tends not to lead to a need for specialization, which leads to further class distinction. Of course there might be small distinctions within a hunter gatherer society, the shaman for ceremony, the big, courageous few to settle disputes with other bands, but the lack of specialization allows for a shared, general skill set. This skill set allows for independence and thus equality (and that's not considering the morphological distinctions of sex but that's another conversation).
Peasants therefore, are part of your unnatural order of human hierarchy.

>i'm more of a let others do their own thing and watch...
I'm of a similar disposition, but I find your insistence on the Jupiterian types being only illusionary to limit the "beautiful and loving" aspects that can evolve from aristocracy. Their refinement of course can lead to greater heights of beauty and terror, but it's still grounded in the potential of all man. Where you see artifice I see a fragile, natural precipice.
For what it's worth, it is my goal to live with the distinction, even if only internally, of nobility, while being grounded by the humility of those closer to the earth

Got to go earlier than that. The large armies with advanced food logistics of Babylon, Egypt etc were already in the throes of aristocratic rule.

Joseph Campbell talks about the origins of farming, and it wasn't organized and hierarchical. It was matriarchal, communal. Then warrior tribes invaded, enslaved, and started enacting better farming methods. Aristocrats are better at maximizing profits, but have absolutely no empathy.
Peasants are largely the former matriarchal type, the Dionysian type. Communal living. I say "peasants" because that's what a lot of them became when the warrior-priests moved in and took everything over. (the elite-peasant dichotomy isn't natural).

>your insistence on the Jupiterian types being only illusionary
that was Nietzsche's terminology, he called it that in Birth of Tragedy. (though he used the term Apollonian, which is the same thing as saying Jupiterian). It's the pretty facade of society, but it's not "real". And it wasn't exactly "nice" either. The vast majority of people were slaves in these types of cultures.
The theory is that farming evolved naturally, and was done on an individual/communal basis, and didn't involve slaves at all. It was the warrior-priest cultures which started the change to slavery and then massive armies
